It is estimated that one billion people around the world don't have access to clean water or affordable health care.
That is a problem that Healthpoint Services wants to solve, but the two-year-old company is not a charity; it's a business with a social mission, and making a profit is critical to its goals.
It's at work in rural India, which is where NPR's John Ydstie went as part of our series on social entrepreneurs.

Driving in rural India is a white-knuckle experience.

It's in places like this where Healthpoint is testing its business plan.
My name is Amit Jain.

Government hospitals are often far away and lines are long.
Healthpoint Services thinks it's got the answer here in a one-story whitewash building set back from the highway.
Amit Jain ushers us in past the pharmacy counter to an exam room where a patient sits next to a white-coated clinical assistant.

This is what the model is all about.

The Healthpoint model combines videoconferencing with cheap diagnostic tests and inexpensive water filtration all in one building.
